body.p: bindingsaboutIn an environment with name spaces, binding references (instances of BindingReference) provide a way to reference a shared variable that makes no assumptions about which name space contains its definition.
Moreover, bindings implement shared objects such as classes, name spaces, and shared variables. Their value is often constant, and they can be referenced, imported, and queried.

References to bindings use a dotted notation that describes the path through the name space hierarchy to the desired binding. Binding references begin with the Root name space, continuing through the hierarchy to the target binding. For example, the full reference to the ButtonHilite constant is: bindingsreferencing dotted namesbinding reference Root.Smalltalk.SymbolicPaintConstants.ButtonHilite

References to bindings in a name space under Smalltalk can omit the initial segment Root.Smalltalk, which is assumed. So, the above reference to ButtonHilite can be shortened to: SymbolicPaintConstants.ButtonHilite
The dotted names can be used to refer to a binding that has not been imported.

Usually you will refer to a binding that has been imported. The notation #{MyBinding} allows referring to the binding MyBinding without specifying its name space path. So, if a name space imports the SymbolicPaintConstants.ButtonHilite, references to it can be simply: #{ButtonHilite}
